Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RUI: Ethics of Care and Compounded Disaster

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
When a disaster strikes, health care workers spring into response, treat the injured and aid the sick. But what happens when disasters keep happening, one after another? How do health care workers cope with the constant demands of disaster conditions? This project documents how health care workers responded to disaster conditions, cared for patients, and worked to rebuild the health care system following a major natural disaster. The research is important because disasters and health emergencies are becoming more frequent and more severe. Therefore, gathering data on how the health care work force responds emotionally to prolonged crisis conditions can aid in designing more effective responses. The broader impacts of this project include the training underrepresented students in anthropology and broadening participation for students underrepresented in science. Data from the project will be disseminated to improve healthcare delivery in post-disaster conditions. This project is jointly funded by Cultural Anthropology, and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR)

This project examines whether the ethics of healthcare provisioning transform under conditions of "compounded disaster," through an investigation of disaster recovery in Puerto Rico, whose infrastructure was devastated by Hurricane Maria in 2017, and was still operating under conditions of sustained emergency at the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic. The central question of this research is: Did health care workers' experiences during and after Hurricane Maria transform their ethics of care? The ethics of care refers to the practices and self-understanding that guide and motivate those who do the work of caring for others. The investigators hypothesize that health care workers developed a new ethics of care that drew upon pre-existing cultural features, but reflects a new sense of solidarity, greater efficacy, and shared purpose forged in the aftermath of Hurricane Maria. The investigators anticipate that this new ethics of care has evolved or transformed through compounding disasters including earthquake swarms and COVID-19. The research design includes data collection through individual interviews, remote focus groups, and on-site participant observation. The project contributes to the scientific understanding of the underlying cultural processes through which disasters transform communities; whether compounded disasters have a geometric or exponential impact on these communities; and also, if the ethics of care fundamentally change under these circumstances. This project generates theory to explain the underlying cultural processes through which (1) disasters transform communities and (2) care workers forge practices and self-understandings that aid in the process of disaster recovery.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When a disaster strikes, health care workers spring into response, treat the injured and aid the sick. But what happens when disasters keep happening, one after another? How do health care workers cope with the constant demands of disaster conditions? This project documents how health care workers responded to disaster conditions, cared for patients, and worked to rebuild the health care system in Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria. The research is important beyond this case because disasters and health emergencies are becoming more frequent and more severe around the globe. Therefore, gathering data on how the health care work force responds emotionally to prolonged crisis conditions can aid in designing more effective responses.

The research design collected data through individual interviews, remote focus groups, and on-site participant observations. During the pilot research and the period funded by NSF, investigators interviewed more than 150 health care professionals and conducted seven focus groups. The project took place during the height of the COVID 19 pandemic, and so, the researchers employed a mix of remote and in person methods to minimize risks. Using these anthropological methods, the study team documented what health care workers were going through emotionally as well as the considerable knowledge resources that they mobilized to solve problems and deliver care under difficult conditions.

The projects’ research question is: Did health care workers’ experiences during & after Hurricane Maria transform their ethics of care? Ethics of care comes from feminist philosophy and refers to the practices and self-understandings that guide and motivate those who do the work of caring for others. The investigators hypothesized that health care workers had developed a new ethics of care that drew on pre-existing cultural features, but reflected a new sense of solidarity, greater efficacy, and shared purpose forged in the aftermath of Hurricane Maria. Five years after Maria, health care workers still talked about their strong commitment to caring for others and their solidarity for their compatriots. However, they also mentioned experiencing burnout and moral injury more frequently which was an important finding from the study.

The results of the study suggest that multifaceted approaches are most likely to improve health care workers’ wellbeing. While increased salaries are certainly desired, other non-remunerative policies were just as important such as flex time to care for their own families; addressing staff shortages; basic supports during emergencies like access to food, water, and device charging stations; symbolic expressions of solidarity, appreciation and respect; and emotional support that included space to process negative work-related emotions and to feel that they were heard by administrators and policymakers. The pervasiveness of moral injury also suggests that improvements to the structure of the health care system will yield marked improvements in health care worker well-being. Structural improvements might include reducing the power of insurance companies to make medical decisions and ration care, addressing chronic underfunding of facilities, equitably funding federal programs like Medicare and Medicaid in Puerto Rico, implementing participatory planning processes that leverage local knowledge, regulating financialization, and appointing qualified experts to lead health agencies.

In addition to improving our understanding of burnout, care ethics, and moral injury for health care workers, the broader impacts of this project also include the educational outcomes of training students in anthropology and expanding the pipeline to science for underrepresented students. Across the two studies included in this collaborative grant, over two dozen undergraduate students were trained in anthropology methods, data analysis, and team research. Many of them have gone on to graduate school and careers in science and public health.
